scenesList.scene_3: Introduction with Dr. Owens and Madeline

start.title:
Optical Illusions: The Geometry Behind What We See

Understanding the Mind’s Visual Interpretation
start.description: In this quest, you'll explore fascinating optical illusions to discover how mathematics reveals hidden patterns. Guided by Mathematical Architect Dr. Elijah Owens and Optical Illusion Artist Madeline Hayes, you'll learn how triangle congruence helps us understand what our eyes perceive versus what mathematics proves.

S2_D1_F4_C0.heading: Welcome to the World of Geometric Illusions!
S2_D1_F4_C0.body: I'm Dr. Elijah Owens, your guide through a world where math and art collide. Together with the talented artist Madeline Hayes, we'll explore optical illusions that challenge what our eyes tell us. Through interactive stations, you'll learn how triangle congruence reveals the truth behind these visual deceptions. Ready to see the world through a new lens? Let’s begin!

S3.S3_D2_F6_C2: Hello everyone! As an artist, I've always been fascinated by how our eyes can be fooled. What looks 'obvious' isn't always true, and that's where the magic happens!
S3.S3_D3_F7_C1: In this exhibition, we'll explore the gap between perception and reality.
S3.S3_D4_F8_C2: You'll discover how your brain sometimes 'sees' things differently than they actually are.
S3.S3_D5_F9_C1: And most importantly, you'll learn how geometric principles can help us uncover the truth behind what we see.
S3.S3_D6_F10_C2: Ready to begin our journey into the world of visual deceptions?
S3.S3_D7_F11_C1: Let's start by exploring some fascinating optical illusions!

S4_D0_F21_C9.title: Optical Illusions Explorer

about.heading: Optical Illusions Explorer
about.body:
Optical illusions demonstrate how our visual perception can be tricked, showing that what we see is not always what is physically present.

Two fascinating illusions you can explore:

  • Café Wall: Straight parallel lines appear to be sloped or wavy due to the arrangement of alternating blocks
  • Hermann Grid: Dark spots appear at the intersections of a grid but vanish when looked at directly

These illusions reveal fundamental aspects of how our visual system processes information and fills in gaps or makes assumptions based on context.

help.heading: Using the Optical Illusions Explorer
help.body:
Controls:

  • Café Wall: Use Show Grid Lines to see true lines
  • Hermann Grid: Use Show Explanation that reveals mechanics

View:

  • Café Wall: Shows how contrast affects perception of parallel lines
  • Hermann Grid: Demonstrates visual artifacts at intersections from retinal processing

ariaLabels.cafe_wall_illusion: A canvas with Black and White Grid structure to explore a visual effect where horizontal lines appear to be slanted due to the arrangement of black and white tiles.
ariaLabels.hermann_grid_illusion: A canvas with Black boxes and white space between them where the purpose is to show an optical illusion where dark spots seem to appear at the intersections of white lines on a black grid.

S4_D0_F21_C9.cafe_wall_illusion_subtitle: These horizontal lines are perfectly parallel!
S4_D0_F21_C9.hermann_grid_illusions_subtitle: Do you see dark spots at the intersections?

S4.S4_D1_F12_C1: Before we dive into geometry, let's experience some famous optical illusions that challenge our perception.
S4.S4_D2_F13_C2: Here are two classic illusions that show how our brains can be tricked.
S4.S4_D3_F14_C1: First, the Café Wall Illusion. These horizontal lines are perfectly straight, but the alternating black and white squares make them appear to wave.
S4.S4_D4_F15_C2: Use the show grid lines option to verify they're straight!
S4.S4_D5_F16_C1: And next, the Hermann Grid. Notice the phantom dark spots that appear at the intersections? They disappear when you look directly at them!
S4.S4_D6_F17_C2: What you're seeing is your brain's visual processing system at work.
S4.S4_D7_F18_C1: All these illusions raise an important question: Can we trust what we see?
S4.S4_D8_F19_C2: This is where mathematics comes in - it gives us tools to discover what's really there.

S5.S5_D1_F20_C1: But where should we start? Let's break down what makes these illusions work.
S5.S5_D2_F21_C2: If you look closely at each illusion we just saw, both trick our perception of lines and angles. The 'Café Wall' distorts horizontal lines and the 'Hermann Grid' creates visual artifacts at intersections.
S5.S5_D3_F22_C1: That's an excellent observation! Angles are the foundation of geometry, and most optical illusions manipulate how we perceive them.
S5.S5_D4_F23_C2: In fact, many optical illusions specifically exploit how our brain processes angles differently than they actually exist mathematically.
S5.S5_D5_F24_C1: Now that we've seen these illusions, let's take a closer look at this fundamental aspect: how our perception of angles can be deceiving and how we can measure this perceptual gap.

S6.S6_D1_F25_C1: Let’s see how much our perception can differ from reality—by putting it to the test!
S6.S6_D2_F26_C2: In this interactive lab, you’ll be shown a <no-glossary>reference angle</no-glossary> on the left side of the screen.
S6.S6_D3_F27_C1: Your challenge is to match that red (right) angle with the blue (left) angle by dragging the slider to the position you think lines up best.
S6.S6_D4_F28_C2: But here’s the twist—you won’t be doing this just once. You’ll be shown four different reference angles, one after another.
S6.S6_D5_F29_C1: Once you're done, we’ll measure how close your recreated angles are to the original.
S6.S6_D6_F30_C2: Ready to test your visual judgment? Follow the instructions and match the red (right) angle with the blue (left) angle.
S6.S6_D7_F29_C1: This activity shows that our perception of angles isn't always accurate. Even basic geometric properties can be misperceived by our visual system.
S6.S6_D8_F30_C2: In art and architecture, we need to account for these perceptual biases. That's why mathematical verification is essential.
S6.S6_D9_F31_C1: The gap between what we see and what's mathematically true creates both fascinating illusions and practical challenges. For example, acute angles often appear smaller than they really are, and obtuse angles look larger.
S6.S6_D10_F32_C2: So how can we verify what's really there when our eyes might be fooled?

S6_D0_F24_C9.title: Angle Perception

about.heading: Angle Perception Lab
about.body:
Visual angle estimation is key to geometric reasoning and spatial skills.

This lab tests your ability to match angles:

  • Blue (left) angle: Reference angle to match
  • Red (right) angle: Your adjustable angle
  • Results show your accuracy and error patterns

Humans typically show predictable error patterns in angle perception, often overestimating acute angles and underestimating obtuse angles.

help.heading: Using the Angle Perception Lab
help.body:
Controls:

  • Adjust the slider to match the red angle to the blue reference angle
  • Click 'Next' to submit and continue
  • View your performance graph after completing all trials

Results:

  • Red bars : Overestimation (your angle was too large)
  • Blue bars : Underestimation (your angle was too small)
  • Zero line: Perfect accuracy

ariaLabels.canvas: Canvas having 2 different angle arrangements with Red and blue color and user have to adjust one of the angle to make it similar as other angle

S6_D0_F24_C9.bar_chart: Bar chart showing angle perception errors

instructions.next: Click on "Next" button to proceed to the next angle.
instructions.show_results: Click on "Show Results" to measure how close your recreated angles are to the original.

S7.S7_D1_F33_C1: We need a geometric shape that's stable and reliable - something that won't change unexpectedly.
S7.S7_D2_F34_C2: That's where triangles come in! They're the simplest polygon that maintains its shape.
S7.S7_D3_F35_C1: Exactly! Unlike triangles, which are rigid once their sides are fixed, quadrilaterals like squares can be distorted - their angles can change even if the side lengths stay the same.
S7.S7_D4_F36_C2: This is why triangles are foundational in architecture and engineering - they provide structural stability.
S7.S7_D5_F37_C1: In the world of optical illusions, this stability gives us a perfect tool to verify what's really there.
S7.S7_D6_F38_C2: So how do we know when two triangles are identical, or congruent?
S7.S7_D14_F46_C1:
There are four key criteria that guarantee congruence between two triangles:
• SSS: When all three corresponding sides of both triangles are equal in length
• SAS: When two corresponding sides and the included angle of both triangles are equal
• ASA: When two corresponding angles and the included side of both triangles are equal
• AAS: When two corresponding angles and a non-included side of both triangles are equal
S7.S7_D15_F47_C2: The amazing thing is that we don't need to check everything - just the right combination of sides and angles.
S7.S7_D16_F48_C1: Let's explore how these triangles behave when we move them around.

S8_D0_F49_C9.title: Triangle Congruence Explorer through Rigid Motions

about.heading: Triangle Congruence Basics
about.body:
Congruent triangles have the same size and shape but may have different positions or orientations.

Four ways to prove triangles are congruent:

  • SSS: Three sides match
  • SAS: Two sides and the included angle match
  • ASA: Two angles and the included side match
  • AAS: Two angles and a non-included side match

Rigid transformations (rotation, translation, reflection) preserve triangle congruence because they don't change shape or size.

help.heading: Using the Triangle Congruence Explorer
help.body:
Controls:

  • Click SSS, SAS, ASA, or AAS buttons to change the congruence criteria
  • Use Rotation slider to rotate the second triangle
  • Use Movement slider to translate the second triangle
  • Click Reflect button to mirror the second triangle
  • Random Reset creates a new random transformation

View:

  • Measurements show sides and angles based on selected criteria

S8_D0_F49_C9.sss_explain: If three sides of one triangle are congruent to three sides of another triangle, the triangles are congruent. This is because rigid motions preserve distances between points.
S8_D0_F49_C9.sas_explain: If two sides and the included angle of one triangle are congruent to two sides and the included angle of another triangle, the triangles are congruent. Rigid motions preserve both distances and angles.
S8_D0_F49_C9.asa_explain: If two angles and the included side of one triangle are congruent to two angles and the included side of another triangle, the triangles are congruent. The third angle is determined by the first two (triangle angle sum is 180°).
S8_D0_F49_C9.aas_explain: If two angles and a non-included side of one triangle are congruent to two angles and a non-included side of another triangle, the triangles are congruent.
S8_D0_F49_C9.canvas: A canvas with a base triangle and a transformed triangle.

S8.S8_D1_F49_C2: Try translating, rotating, and reflecting these triangles in our interactive tool.
S8.S8_D2_F50_C1: Notice how the measurements stay constant no matter how you move them?
S8.S8_D3_F51_C2: These movements - translation, rotation, and reflection - preserve all the properties of a triangle.
S8.S8_D4_F52_C1: These are called rigid motions - mathematical tools that help us verify when shapes are truly identical, even if they appear different.
S8.S8_D4_F53_C2: And here's the connection: if two triangles meet one of the congruence criteria - SSS, SAS, ASA, or AAS - we can use rigid motions to show that they're physically identical, too.
S8.S8_D5_F53_C2: Take a moment to experiment with the interactive tool. Try translating (sliding) Triangle B to line it up with Triangle A and observe how its measurements remain unchanged.
S8.S8_D6_F54_C1: Now try rotating Triangle B around its center. Notice how all the angles and side lengths stay exactly the same?
S8.S8_D6_F54X_C1: Great job! Rigid motions preserve both the angles and side lengths of geometric shapes.
S8.S8_D7_F55_C2: Finally, try reflecting Triangle B. Even though its orientation has changed, it's still congruent to Triangle A!
S8.S8_D8_F56_C1: Which of these transformations is NOT a rigid motion?
S8.S8_D9_F57_C2: Correct! Stretching changes the side lengths, so it's not a rigid motion. Only transformations that preserve all measurements are rigid motions.
S8.S8_D9_F57X_C1: These transformations demonstrate an important principle: congruent shapes can be mapped onto each other through rigid motions.
S8.S8_D9_F57Y_C2: Now you have the tools to uncover the truth behind what you see! But so far, we've been working with triangles that are clearly visible.
S8.S8_D9_F57Z_C1: What if I told you that your brain sometimes creates geometric shapes that aren't even fully drawn?
S8.S8_D9_F57XY_C2: That's right! There's a fascinating phenomenon where your visual system can actually see shapes that aren't completely there in reality.

S9.S9_D1_F58_C2: We've explored how triangles can be proven congruent through measurements. Now, let's push this concept further with something truly fascinating.
S9.S9_D2_F59_C1: This next installation bridges my architectural work with Madeline's artistic vision - it's about how our visual system creates structure where there is none.
S9.S9_D3_F60_C2: The Kanizsa triangle demonstrates a phenomenon called 'boundary completion.' Unlike the previous illusions where we misperceived existing elements, here our brains actually construct elements that aren't physically present.

about.heading: Kanizsa Triangle Basics
about.body:
The Kanizsa triangle is a famous optical illusion where we perceive a white triangle that doesn't actually exist.

Key Concepts:

  • Our brain automatically "fills in" missing information
  • The black Pac-Man shapes create illusory contours
  • Triangle congruence can be tested using four methods (SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS)
  • Two triangles are congruent if any one of the congruence criteria is satisfied for the triangles

This illusion demonstrates how our visual system creates coherent shapes from incomplete information, similar to how we perceive objects in the real world even when partially hidden.

help.heading: Using the Kanizsa Triangle Explorer
help.body:
• Toggle "Show Triangle Lines" to reveal the hidden triangles
  • Use "Show Measurements" to display angles and side lengths
  • Click "Test Congruence" to automatically analyze which congruence criteria (SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS) are satisfied
  • The system will show you which criteria apply and provide detailed explanations
  • Reset view clears all selections and returns to the starting display

scenario1.name: Scenario 1: Identical Triangles
scenario1.description: In this scenario, the Pac-Man shapes form identical triangles.

explanations.SSS: The triangles are congruent by SSS because all three pairs of corresponding sides are equal: side a = 141.4, side b = 141.4, and side c = 141.4 in both triangles.
explanations.SAS: The triangles are congruent by SAS because two sides and their included angle are equal. For example, sides b = 141.4 and c = 141.4 and their included angle A = 60° match in both triangles.
explanations.ASA: The triangles are congruent by ASA because two angles and their included side are equal. For example, angles B = 60° and C = 60° and their included side a = 141.4 match in both triangles.
explanations.AAS: The triangles are congruent by AAS because two angles and a non-included side are equal. For example, angles A = 60° and B = 60° and the non-included side a = 141.4 match in both triangles.

scenario2.name: Scenario 2: Two Equal Sides, One Unknown
scenario2.description: In this scenario, two sides are equal, but the third is unknown.

explanations.SAS: The triangles are congruent by SAS because two sides and their included angle are equal. Sides a = 120 and b = 120 and their included angle C = 50° match in both triangles.
explanations.ASA: The triangles are congruent by ASA because two angles and their included side are equal. Angles A = 65° and B = 65° and their included side c = 101.45 match in both triangles.
explanations.AAS: The triangles are congruent by AAS because two angles and a non-included side are equal. Angles A = 65° and B = 65° and the non-included side a = 120 match in both triangles.

scenario3.name: Scenario 3: Equal Angles, Different Sides
scenario3.description: In this scenario, angles are equal but the sides have different lengths.

explanations.SSS: The triangles are NOT congruent by SSS because all sides differ in length. Triangle 1 has sides a = 141.4, b = 141.4, c = 141.4, while Triangle 2 has sides a = 180, b = 180, c = 180. The triangles are similar (same shape, different size), but not congruent.
explanations.SAS: The triangles are NOT congruent by SAS. Although their angles match (A = 60°, B = 60°, C = 60°), the sides have different lengths. Triangle 1 has sides b = 141.4, c = 141.4, while Triangle 2 has sides b = 180, c = 180.
explanations.ASA: The triangles are NOT congruent by ASA. Although the angles match (B = 60°, C = 60°), the included side a differs in length. Triangle 1 has side a = 141.4, while Triangle 2 has side a = 180. The triangles are similar but not congruent.
explanations.AAS: The triangles are NOT congruent by AAS. Although the angles match (A = 60°, B = 60°), the non-included side a differs in length. Triangle 1 has side a = 141.4, while Triangle 2 has side a = 180. The triangles are similar but not congruent.

congruence.not_congruent_explanation: These triangles are NOT congruent. No congruence criteria (SSS, SAS, ASA, or AAS) are satisfied based on the available measurements.
congruence.congruent_explanation: These triangles are congruent! They satisfy the following congruence criteria:

S10.S10_D1_F61_C1: What do you see in this pattern of black shapes?
S10.S10_D2_F62_C2: Most people perceive a white triangle floating above the pattern, appearing brighter than the background. Yet there's no complete triangle actually drawn!
S10.S10_D3_F63_C1: This shows the brain's constructive powers. Try clicking the "Show Triangle Lines" button to reveal what your brain is filling in.
S10.S10_D4_F64_C2: Notice how those black "Pac-Man" shapes position the corners of the triangle your brain perceives. Now click "Show Measurements" to see the mathematical properties of these illusory triangles.
S10.S10_D5_FX_C1: Let's explore three different scenarios and verify our observations. We will use the following criteria to determine whether the triangles are congruent: SSS, SAS, ASA, and AAS. If any of these criteria are satisfied, we can conclude that the triangles are congruent.
S10.S10_D6_FX_C1: Click the "Test Congruence" button to check whether the triangles are congruent.
S10.S10_D7_FX_C2: The triangles are congruent. All four criteria — SSS, SAS, ASA, and AAS — are satisfied with the given information.
S10.S10_D8_FX_C1: That won't always be the case. Let's examine the second scenario.
S10.S10_D9_FX_C1: Click the "Show Measurements" button to view the side and angle values, then click the "Test Congruence" button to determine if the triangles are congruent.
S10.S10_D10_FX_C2: The triangles are congruent. However, this time, only three criteria are satisfied with the given information: SAS, ASA, and AAS.
S10.S10_D11_FX_C1: Exactly. The applicable congruence criteria depend on the measurements provided in the triangles. Now, let's move on to the third scenario.
S10.S10_D12_FX_C1: Click the "Show Measurements" button to view the side and angle values, then click the "Test Congruence" button to determine if the triangles are congruent.
S10.S10_D13_FX_C2: The triangles are not congruent, as none of the criteria are satisfied.
S10.S10_D14_FX_C1: That was impressive work. You've sharpened your understanding of congruence and perception.
S10.S10_D15_FX_C2: It's fascinating how geometry helps us reveal patterns hidden in plain sight.
S10.S10_D16_FX_C1: Let’s continue our journey. There’s more to explore — stay curious!

S11_D0_F93_C9.title: Helmholtz Square Illusion

about.heading: Geometric Illusions Explorer
about.body:
Geometric illusions reveal how our visual system misinterprets shapes, angles, and lines based on surrounding context.

  • This interactive explores how your brain processes visual information through the Helmholtz Square Illusion, where identical squares seem to have different dimensions based on internal line orientation.
  • This illusion demonstrates how context dramatically impacts our perception of geometric properties.

help.heading: Using the Geometric Illusions Explorer
help.body:
Controls:

  • Use the slider to translate Square B and overlap it with Square A
  • Reset Position: Returns Square B to its original position

S11_D0_F93_C9.helmholtz_description: A square divided by horizontal lines (Square A) appears taller than the same square divided by vertical lines (Square B).

labels.straight_lines: The red lines are perfectly straight!
labels.taller_appearance: Square A with horizontal lines appears taller
labels.translate_square_b: Translate Square B to make it overlap with Square A
labels.squares_aligned: Squares are perfectly aligned! They are identical in size.

accessibility.illusion_description: Square A with horizontal lines on the left, Square B with vertical lines on the right.
accessibility.squares_aligned_state: Squares are now perfectly aligned and overlapping.
accessibility.square_b_translated: Square B is {percentage}% translated to the left.
accessibility.reset_button_description: Square B will return to its original position

S11.S11_D1_FX_C1: Look at these two squares in the Helmholtz Illusion. The one with horizontal lines (Square A) appears taller, while the one with vertical lines (Square B) looks wider.
S11.S11_D2_FX_C2: But are they actually different? Translate the Square B to make it overlap with the Square A and verify the results.
S11.S11_D3_FX_C1: Excellent! You've confirmed both squares are identical — you've applied <no-glossary>translation</no-glossary> to reveal the truth behind what your eyes perceived.

S12.S12_D1_F100_C2: You've come full circle - from being fooled by illusions to using mathematics to discover reality.
S12.S12_D2_F101_C2: We started with simple optical illusions and discovered how our perception—especially of angles—can be misleading.
S12.S12_D3_F102_C1: Along the way, we explored how triangle congruence gives us a powerful mathematical tool to confirm what’s truly identical, even when our eyes might disagree.
S12.S12_D3_F103_C2: While we didn’t use congruence to solve every illusion, it gave us a framework to think critically about what we see versus what’s actually there.
S12.S12_D4_F104_C1: And that brought us to the Kanizsa Triangle—a perfect example of how the brain can go beyond misjudging reality and actually construct shapes from incomplete information.
S12.S12_D4_F103_C2: Triangle congruence gives us powerful tools to verify what's actually there, beyond what our eyes tell us.
S12.S12_D5_F104_C1: This knowledge isn't just for solving puzzles - it has real applications in art, architecture, computer vision, and many other fields.
S12.S12_D6_F105_C2: The next time you encounter something that looks impossible or confusing...
S12.S12_D7_F106_C1: Remember: let geometry reveal the truth!

quest_completion.subheading: You have conquered Optical Illusions: The Geometry Behind What We See
quest_completion.content:
You have completed the Optical Illusions STEAMQuest!

  • You discovered how optical illusions reveal the gap between perception and reality
  • You analyzed perceptual errors in angle recognition
  • You explored the four criteria for triangle congruence: SSS, SAS, ASA and AAS
  • You discovered how to use rigid motions to verify geometric properties
  • You explored how congruence principles can help us understand visual stability—even when illusions trick our perception
Your ability to analyze visual patterns helped to bridge the gap between perception and mathematical reality!

congruent.definition: Congruent means when two geometric figures that have exactly the same size and shape, regardless of their position or orientation.

translation.definition: Translation is a transformation that slides a figure the same distance and in the same direction without rotating or flipping it.

rigid-motions.definition: Rigid motion is a transformation that moves a shape without changing its size or shape (includes rotation, reflection, and translation).

optical-illusions.definition: Optical illusion is a visual image that differs from objective reality, where our brain interprets something differently from its actual physical properties.

optical-illusion.definition: Optical illusion is a visual image that differs from objective reality, where our brain interprets something differently from its actual physical properties.

sas.definition: SAS congruency criterion is when two sides and the included angle are equal, triangles are congruent.

sss.definition: SSS congruency criterion is when if three sides are equal, triangles are congruent.

asa.definition: ASA congruency criterion is when two angles and the included side are equal, triangles are congruent.

aas.definition: AAS congruency criterion is when two angles and a non-included side are equal, triangles are congruent.

regression.definition: Regression is a statistical method used to model and analyze relationships between variables, often represented by a trend line on a scatter plot.

trend-lines.definition: Trend line is a line on a scatter plot drawn near the points. It shows a correlation and can be used to make predictions.

overabundance.definition: Overabundance is an excessive quantity or surplus of organisms in an ecosystem, typically resulting from a disruption in natural predator-prey relationships and potentially causing environmental imbalance.

scatter-plot.definition: Scatter plot is a graph that relates two different sets of data by plotting the data as ordered pairs. You can use a scatter plot to determine a relationship between the data sets.

linear-equations.definition: Linear equations are functions whose graph is a line. You can represent a linear function with a linear equation.

correlation.definition: Correlation indicates the strength of a relationship between two data sets.

causation.definition: Causation is a direct relationship where a change in one variable directly causes a change in another variable.

polygon.definition: Polygon is a closed plane figure formed by three or more segments that do not intersect except at their endpoints.

rotation.definition: Rotation is a rigid motion that turns a figure around a fixed point, called the center of rotation, by a certain angle.

reflection.definition: Reflection is a transformation that flips a figure across a line, creating a mirror image.

transformations.definition: Transformations are operations that move, rotate, reflect, or change the size of geometric figures while preserving their essential properties.
